International A3-11
China's leader demanded restraint, warning that chaos in Beijing was spreading all over the country, but he was ignored by up to a million people demonstrating for greater democracy. Page A1
A hunger strike has stirred China and led to mass demonstrations for more democracy, including calls for the resignation of the nation's top leaders. A1
At the center of China's latest storm is Qin Benli, an editor. The Communist Party's crackdown on his weekly newspaper has prompted journalists to support pro-democracy demonstrations. A10
Muscovites are not optimistic about any short-run hopes for additional consumer goods from Mr. Gorbachev's mission. But they are relieved about the pledges of greater tranquillity on the border. A1
Lithuania wants independence, the legislature of the Soviet republic declared. It was the first time that the Lithuanian government added its voice to the movement. A1
The rebels still surround Jalalabad, despite Government claims to have recaptured a 25-mile stretch east of the city. A11
Pakistan's nuclear abilities are being developed while India has begun research that could be used to make thermonuclear weapons, William H. Webster told Congress. A7
Panama violated the Canal treaties more than 1,200 times in the last 15 months by harassing United States military personnel and their dependents, a U.S. official said. A3
Panamanians are under stress since many are convinced that a happy resolution of their 18-month political crisis has receded. A3

Nearly two months after the oil spill, Alaskan officials say not a single mile of beach has been completely cleaned and that the death toll of birds, fish and mammals still mounts. A1
The alcoholism of the tanker captain who went aground March 24 in Prince William Sound, had been monitored by the Exxon Shipping Company for four years, the company president testified. B5
Exxon's chairman faced the owners of the company for the first time since the oil spill in Alaska 8 weeks ago, and showed a combination of confidence and exasperation. B5
The first repairs on aging airliners that will eventually involve 2,200 planes and cost the airline industry hundreds of millions of dollars was ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration. A1
Consumer inflation jumped seven-tenths of one percent in April, driven by the largest one-month increase on record in the price of gasoline, the Government said. A1

Visas for foreigners with AIDS will be granted by the immigration service on a temporary basis for conferences or medical treatment, a Justice Department official said. D16 House Speaker Jim Wright predicted victory in his legal challenge to the ethics charges against him. D16
In a historic advertising switch, the Burger King Corporation transferred its domestic business from N.W. Ayer to two other agencies. D1
William J. Bennett met with students at a Miami school to do something that is virtually unthinkable among teen-agers: tell on friends who are taking drugs. A12
A Florida girl may have an abortion without her parents' consent or knowledge as the result of a U.S. Supreme Court decision to lift a stay imposed by one of its Justices. A12
Chrysler has agreed to buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc. for $263 million in cash to cement its relationship with an important customer in the automobile rental market. D1

Mayor Edward I. Koch's new budget could provide more police officers, prosecutors and child-welfare caseworkers, more jail beds and ambulance service, and smaller shelters for the homeless. A1
Uniformed services will be increased under Mayor Edward I. Koch's $26.6 billion budget. The Mayor proposed hiring more than 4,000 new police and correction officers. B4
Mayor Koch's proposed budget cuts would be felt keenly, as libraries close on some days, new playgrounds go unbuilt, museums curtail operations and parks get dirtier. B4

Connecticut's finances are worse than they were three months ago, when Governor William A. O'Neill proposed the largest tax increase in state history.
